content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of homeless veterans for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. It also establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving the most healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The program will be carried out at six locations, including cities with the largest homeless veteran populations and suburban or rural settings. The program established by the "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" will provide intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans in six locations, including cities with the largest homeless veteran populations and suburban or rural settings. The Secretary will select locations based on high interaction and coordination between the Department of Veterans Affairs and community organizations providing housing and social services for veterans. Intensive case management interventions will be provided to at least 20 covered veterans at each location who receive the most health care and related services from the Department. The Secretary will provide intensive case management interventions to at least 20 covered veterans at selected locations to improve housing stability and access to health care services. This includes assistance with gaining and maintaining access to housing, benefits, and services under the laws administered by the Secretary. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will commence intensive case management interventions by September 1, 2016, for at least 20 covered veterans to improve housing stability and access to healthcare services. A report on the program must be submitted by December 1, 2018, including assessments of the types and frequencies of interventions, housing status, and employment status of veterans who received the interventions. The program requires intensive case management interventions for covered veterans to improve housing stability, access to healthcare services, employment status, and utilization of VA services. The report due by December 1, 2018, will include assessments of the interventions provided and their impact on veterans. The report due by December 1, 2018, will include assessments of the interventions provided under the program, including the number of veterans receiving intensive case management, costs incurred, and estimated costs for health care services. The report will include assessments of intensive case management interventions provided to veterans, estimated costs for health care services, and costs saved by implementing the program in specific locations. Program to improve retention of housing by formerly homeless veterans and veterans at risk of becoming homeless. The Secretary is required to implement a program providing case management services to help formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness retain housing. Grants will be awarded to organizations with a proven ability to offer these services, with priority given to those experienced in transitional housing. The Secretary prioritizes organizations with experience in transitional housing services when awarding grants for case management services to help homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Extra priority is given to organizations that voluntarily transition from providing transitional housing to permanent housing that meets housing quality standards. The organization prioritizes experienced transitional housing providers for grants to assist homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Priority is given to organizations transitioning voluntarily from transitional to permanent housing that meets quality standards. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will prescribe regulations to carry out a program aimed at improving housing retention for formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. A report assessing the program's effectiveness in helping veterans retain permanent housing must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019. The report on the program will assess the percentage of veterans retaining permanent housing, those not in permanent housing, use of housing assistance by veterans, and the employment status of veterans receiving case management services. The report will assess the employment status of veterans who received case management services, comparing before and after receiving the services. SEC. 5. EXPANSION OF HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM OF DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to assist homeless veterans, veterans at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families in acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy in permanent housing. The amendment to Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code, aims to provide permanent or transitional housing for veterans and families, ensuring they receive referrals for entitled benefits and services. The amendment to Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code aims to ensure veterans receiving housing also receive referrals for entitled benefits and services. Additionally, the amendment expands eligibility to include veterans and families described in paragraph (1). The Secretary of Veterans Affairs collaborates with various entities to increase housing availability for veterans. Outreach efforts target realtors, landlords, and developers to educate them on veterans' housing needs. A National Center on Homelessness among Veterans is established. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs establishes the National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to conduct research, assess program effectiveness, and disseminate best practices for addressing veteran homelessness. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans is established by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to assess program effectiveness, disseminate best practices, integrate evidence-based policies, and serve as a resource center for research and training activities related to veteran homelessness. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans is established to coordinate information exchange on research and training activities related to veteran homelessness. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans is established to coordinate research and training activities related to veteran homelessness. Administrative improvements are made to the grant and per diem programs of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code is amended to include a new subsection (e) which requires the Secretary to annually review grant recipients and eligible entities that received per diem payments to evaluate their performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. The Secretary must annually review grant recipients and eligible entities to evaluate their performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. Per diem payments will only be provided to those who merit continued receipt based on performance. Uniform performance targets will be established nationwide for evaluation purposes.
